editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: SAUNY the SCOT. OR, THE Taming of the Shrew.
Sauny the Scott: OR, THE Taming of the Shrew: A COMEDY.
As it is now ACTED at the THEATRE-ROYAL.
Written by J. LACEY, Servant to His MAJESTY.
div.l: Then I'll cry out, Swell'd with Poetick Rage,
'Tis I, John Lacy, have Reform'd your Stage.
div.p: London, Printed and Sold by E. Whitlock, near Stationers-Hall. 1698.

div.head: SAUNEY the SCOT: OR, The Taming of the SHREW.

div.stage: Enter Winlove, and his Man Tranio.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I Am quite weary of the Country Life; there is that Little thing the World calls Quiet, but there is nothing else; Clowns live and die in't, whose Souls lye hid here, and after Death their Names: My Kinder Stars, (I thank 'em) have Wing'd my Spirit with an Active Fire, which makes me wish to know what Men are Born for, to Dyet a Running Horse, to give a Hawk casting, to know Dogs Names; These make not Men; no, 'tis Philosophy, 'tis Learning, and Exercise of Reason to know what's Good and Virtuous, and to break our Stubborn and Untemper'd Wills, to Choose it; This makes us Imitate that Great Divinity that Fram'd us.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I thought you had Learn't Philosophy enough at Oxford, what betwixt Aristotle on one side, and Bottle-Ale on the other, I am confident you have arriv'd at a Pitch of Learning and Virtue sufficient for any Gentleman to set up with in the Countrey, that is, to be the Prop of the Family.

sp.speaker: Winl.
sp.p: My Father's Fondness has kept me so long in the Country, I've forgot all I'd Learn't at the University: Besides, take that at Best, it but Rough-casts us; No, London is the Choisest Academy, 'tis that must Polish us, and put a Gloss upon our Country-Studies; Hither I'm come at last, and do resolve to Glean many Vices. Thou, Tranio, hast been my Companion, still one Bed has held us, one Table fed us; and tho' our Bloods give me Precedency (that I count Chance) My Love has made us Equal, and I have found a frank return in thee.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Such a Discourse commands a Serious Answer; Know then, your Kindness tells me, I must Love you: The Good you have Taught me Commands me to Honour you; I have Learnt, with you, to hate Ingratitude; But setting those aside, for thus I may seem to do it: for my own sake, be assur'd, I must Love you, though you hate me; I neither look at Vice nor Virtue in you, but as you are the Person I dote on.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: No more; I do believe and know thou lov'st me: I wonder Iamy stays so long behind: You must look out to get me handsome Lodgings, sit to receive such Friends the Town shall bring me; you must take care of all, for I'm resolv'd to make my Study my sole Business; I'll live handsomly, not over high, nor yet beneath my Quality.

div.stage: Enter Beaufoy, Margaret, Biancha, Woodall, and Geraldo. But stay a little, What Company's this?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Gentlemen, Importune no farther, you know my firm Resolve, not to bestow my Youngest Daughter, before I have a Husband for the Elder; if either of you both Love Pegg, because I know you well, and love you well: You shall have freedom to Court her at your Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That is to say, we shall have leave to have our Heads broken, a prime Kindness, by'ur Lady, she's too rough for me; There, Geraldo, take her for me, if you have any Mind to a Wife; to her, you are Young, and may clap Trammel's on her, and strike her to a Pace in time; I dare not deal with her, I shall never get her out of her high Trot.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: 'Tis strange, Sir, you should make a Stale of me among these Mates thus.

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: Mates, Madam, 'Faith, no Mates for you, unless you were a little Tamer; wo worth him that has the Breaking of you?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Take heed I don't bestow the Breaking of your Calves Head for you; You Mate, Marry come up; go, get you a Sempstress, and run in Score with her for Muckinders to dry your Nose with, and Marry her at last to pay the Debt: And you there, Goodman Turnep-eater, with your Neats-Leather Phisnomy, I'll send your Kitchen-wench to Liquor it this Wet-weather; Whose old Bootes was it cut out of?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: From all such Potticoate Devils deliver us I pray.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Did you ever see the like, Sir? that Wench is either stark Mad, or wonderful Froward.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I can't tell, but I had as live take her Dowry with this condition, to be whipt at Chairing-cross every morning.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Faith as you say, there's small choice in rotten Apples, but since 'tis as 'tis, let us be Friendly Rivals, and endeavour for a Husband for Margaret, that Biancha may be free to have one, and then he that can win her, wear her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I would give the best Horse in Smith-field to him that would throughly Woe her, Wed her, and Bed her, and rid the House of her, to carry her far enough of, well come agreed.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: But pray Sir, is't possible that Love should of a sudden take such hold of you.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: O Tranio, till I found it to be true, I never found it possible, but she has such attractive Charms, he were a stone that did not Love her, I am all fire, burn, pine, perish Tranio, unless I win her; Counsel me, and Assist me, Dear Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Are all your Resolutions for Study come to this? you have got a book will hold you tack, you are like to be a fine Virtuoso, now must we to a Chymist to set his Still a going for Philters—Love Powders and Extracts of Sigh's and Highoe's.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Nay Tranio, do not make Sport with my Passion, it is a thing so deeply rooted here, it cannot dye, but it must take me with it; help me, or hope not long to see thy Master?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p:
Nay Sir, if you are so far gone there's no remedy, we must contrive
some way, but 'twill be difficult; for you know her Father has mew'd her up, and till he has rid his hands of her Sister there's no coming near her.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Ah, Tranio, what a cruel Father's he, but don't you remember what care he took to provide Masters for her.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I Sir, and what of all that?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Y'are a Fool, can't I be perfer'd to her, to teach her French, I have a good command of the Language, and it may be easily done.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I don't apprehend the easiness of it; for who shall be Sir Lyonels Son here in Town? To ply his Studyes, and wellcome his Friends, visit his Kindred, and entertain 'em.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Be content, I have a Salve for that too; we have not yet been seen in any House, nor can be distinguish'd by our Faces, for Man or Master. Then it follows thus, you Tranio must be young Winlove in my stead, and bear your self according to my rank; I'll be an ordinary French Master about the Town, the time I stay'd in France, in that will help me, it must be so. Come, come, unease, and take my Cloath's and when we're at our Lodgings, we'll make a full change; when Iamy comes he waits on thee, but first I'll charme his Tongue.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: 'Twill be needful, since this is your Pleasure I'me ty'd to be Obedient, for so your Father charg'd me at your Parting, altho I think 'twas in another sence; In short I'm ready to serve you, and assist you in your Enterprize.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Here comes the Rogue. Sirrah, Where have you been?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Where have I been? Pray how now Master, where are you Master, has Tranio Stoln your Cloathes, or you his, or both?

sp.speaker: Winl.
sp.p: Sirrah come hither, this is not time to Jest. Some weighty Reason makes me take this Habit; enquire not; you shall know e'm time enough; mean while wait you on Tranio in my stead I charge you as becomes you, you understand me.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: I, Sir, ne'r a whit.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: And not of Tranio; one word in your Mouth, he's turn'd to Winlove.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: The better for him, would I were so too.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: When I am alone with you, why then I am Tranio still, in all places else, your Master VVinlove.

sp.speaker: VVinl.
sp.p: Tranio, let's go, one thing yet remains, which you must by no means neglect, that is, to make one amongst these Wars; Ask me not why, but be satisfy'd, my Reasons are both good and weighty.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I obey, Sir.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter Petruchio, and his Man Sauny.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: SIrrah, leave off your Scotch, and speak me English, or something like it.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gude will I Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I think we have Ridden Twenty Miles in Three houres, Sawny are the Horses well Rubb'd down and Litter'd.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Deel O my Saul, Sir, I ne'r Scrub'd my sell better than I Scrub'd your Naggs.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And thou need'st Scrubbing, I'll say that for thee, thou Beastly Knave; Why do ye not get your self Cur'd of the Mange.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed, Sir, I w'ud ne'a be cur'd for a Thousand Pund; there's nea a Lad in aw Scotland but Loves it; Gude Sawny might hang himsel an it were not for Scratting and Scubbing.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why so Prethee?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: When ye gea 'tull a Ladies House ye are Blith and Bonny Sir, and gat gud Meat, but the Dee'l a bit gat's Sawndy, meere than Hunger and Cawd, Sir; Ba then, Sir, when aw the Footmen stan still Sir, and ha nothing to dea, then gees Saundy tul his Pastime, Scratten and Scrubben.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Do'st call it Pastime?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: A my Saul de I Sir; I take as Muckle Pleasure, Sir, in Scratten and Scrubben, as ye de in Tiplin and Mowing.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, if it be so, keep it, and much good may it d'ye. This is my old Friend Geraldo's Lodgings, for whose sake now I am come to Town, I hope he's at home; there Sauny, Knock.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Wuns, Sir, I see nean to Knock boe' yer ean sel, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sirrah, I say Knock me soundly at this Gate.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Out, Out, in the Muccle Dee'ls Name t' ye; you'l gar me strike ye, and then ye'l put me a-wau, Sir, with ye'r favour Ise ne're do't Sir: Gude an ye ne ken when ye an a gued Man, S'breed I wo't when I've a gued Master, ye's bang yer Sel for Saundy.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Rogue, I'll make you understand me.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gude an yeed give Sawndy ea bang ar twa mere e that place, for I can ne're come at it to Scrat it my sel Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Yes thus, Sir.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: The Dee'l faw yer Fingers, I may not beat yea o' yee'r e'ne Dunghill, Sir, bot gin I had yea in Scotland, Is'e ne give yea a Bawbee for your Luggs.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: How now Sauny, What Crying out? Dear Petruchio, most wellcome; When came you to Town? What Quarrel is this 'twixt you and Sauny? I pray let me Compose the Difference, and tell me now what happy Gale droye you to Town, and why in this Habbit? Why in Mourning?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A common Calamity to us young Men, my Father has been Dead this four Mouths.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Trust me I am sorry, a good old Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gee yer gate Sir, ge yer gate, on ye be fow a grief ye'r nea Friend, Sir, we are blyth and bonny, Sir, we nere woe for't.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sirrah, you long to be basted.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gad do I not, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Hether I come to try my Fortunes, to see if good luck and my Friends will help me to a Wife; Will you wish me to one?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: What Quallifications do you look for?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why Money, a good Portion.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: All Man? all other things are in my making.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I shall come roundly to you, and wish you to a Rich Wife, but her Face—

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: That shall break no Squares, a Mask will mend it, wealth is the burthen of my Wooing Song. If she be Rich, I care not if she want a Nose or an Eye, any thing with Money.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: De ye nea gi him Creedit Sir, I wud a halp't him tul a Highland Lady with Twanty thousand pund; Gude he wud nea have her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sirrah, your Twenty thousand Pounds Scotch will make but a Pittiful English portion.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gude Sir, Bo a Muckle deal of Scotch Punds is as gued as a Little deale of English Punds.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She has nothing like this, but a thing worse, she has a Tongue that keep's more Noise then all that ever Mov'd at Billingsgate.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Pish, a triffle; Where lives she? I long to be Wooing her, let me alone with her Tongue, I'me in Love with the new's of it, who is't? who is't? I'm resolv'd for her or Nobody.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: But look before you Leap, Sir, and say you were warn'd.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Out, out, he can nea break his Cragg upon her, Gude an ye'd venter your bonny Lass, Ise venter my bonna Lad at her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Her Father is the brave Noble Beaufoy, her Name Margaret, fam'd about Town for a Vixen.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: The Town's an Ass, come prithee shew me the House, I will not sleep 'till I see her, I know her Father. Nay, I am resolv'd man, come prithee come.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Wun's man an she be a Scawd, awaw with her, awaw with her, and Iohnee Iohnstons Curse go with Her.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Prethee what's that?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: That is, the Deel creep into her weem t'ith very bottome on't that's to the Croone gued faith of her head.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Well Sir, if you are resolv'd, I'll wait on you; to say the truth, 'twill be my great advantage, for if you win her, I shall have liberty to see her younger Sister sweet Biancha, to whose fair Eyes I am a Votary, and you in order to my Love Petruchio must help me, I'll tell you why, and how you must prefer me as a Musick-Master to old Beaufoy.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: He'd ha ye make him her Piper, Sir, gued at ye'd make Sanndy her Piper, wun's Ide sea blea her Pipe.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sirrah be quiet, what I can I'll serve you in; But who comes here Geraldo?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: 'Tis Mr. Woodall, a rich old Citizen, and my Rival: Hark.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Out, out, What sud an awd Carle do with a young bonny Lass, are ye not an Aud theif, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Are ye not an Aud Man, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes marry am I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: And are not ye to Marry a young Maiden?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yes, What then?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: And are not ye troubled with a sear griefe, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: A sear grief, what sear grief?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Your troubled with a great weakness i'th' bottome of your Bally, what sid yea dea with a young Maiden? Out, out, out.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: You understand me, your French Books treat most of Love; those use her too, and now and then you may urge something of my Love and Merit? besides her Fathers bounty, you shall find me Liberal.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Mounsier, me will tell her the very fine ting of you, me vill make her Love you whether she can or noe?

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Enough, Peace, here's Geraldo, your servant Sir, I am just going to Sir Nicholas Beaufoy to carry him this Gentleman, a Frenchman, most Eminent for teaching his Country Language.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I have a Master for Biancha too, but waving that, I have some news to tell you, I have found out a Friend that will Woo Margaret, What will you contribute, for he must be hir'd to't?

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Why I will give him forty Peeces in hand, and when he has don't, I'll double the Sum.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Done, Sir, I'll undertake it.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed Sir, I'se gat it done muckle Cheaper, for twanty Punds I'se dea it my Sel.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Come, down with your Money, and the Bargain's made.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: But if He shud not do it, I don't care for throwing away so much Money.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: If he don't I'll undertake he shall refund.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Why then here's ten Pieces, and that Ring I'll pawn to you for 'tother Forty, 'tis worth a Hundred; But doe's the Gentleman know her Qualities?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I Sir, and they are such as I am fond on; I woul'd not be hir'd for any thing, to Woo a person of another Humour.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Save you Gentlemen; Pray which is the way to Sir Nicholas Beaufoy's House?

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Why Sir, what's your Business there? you pretend not to be a Servant to either of his Daughters, d' ye?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: You are something blunt in your Questions, perhaps I do.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Not her that Chides, on any hand I pray.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I Love no Chiders; come Iamy.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Pray stay Sir, Is it the other?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: May be it is, Is it any offence?

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Yes 'tis Sir, she is my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I must tell you Sir, she is my Mistriss too.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: And I must tell you both she is my Mistriss; Will that content you? nay never frown for the Matter.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: And I mun tell ye all, there's little hopes for Saundy then.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: The Rogue does it rarely.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Gentleman, no Quarrelling, unless it were to the purpose: Have you seen this young Lady Sir?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: No Sir: but I'm in Love with her Character. They say she has a Sister moves like a Whirlwind.

sp.speaker: Pet.
Tran.
sp.p: I thank you for your Admonition; I should have lost my Labour else; and since you are to do all of us the Favour, I shall be glad to be numbred among your Servants Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You will honour me to accept of me for yours. But pray Sir let me know who obliges me with this Civility?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: My Name is VVinlove, Sir, a VVorstershire Gentleman; where I have something, an Old Man's Death will Intitle me to, not inconsiderable. Come, Gentlemen, let's not fall out, at least till the Fair Biancha's at Liberty; Shall we go sit out half an hour at the Tavern, and Drink her Health?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Do my Bearns; and I'se Drink with ye to Countenance ye.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I, I, agreed; Come, and then I'll to my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gude these Lades are o' Saundyes Mind, they'l lather take a Drink, nor Flight.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Marry come up Proud Slut, Must you be making your self Fine before your Elder Sister? You are the Favourite you are, but I shall make you know your Distance; Give me that Necklace, and those Pendants, I'll have that Whisk too, there's an old Handkerchief good enough for you.

sp.speaker: Bianc.
sp.p: Here, take 'em, Sister, I resign 'em freely, I wou'd give you all I have to Purchase your Kindness.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You Flattering Gypsie, I cou'd find in my Heart to Slit your Dissembling Tongue; Come, tell me and without Lying, which of your Sutors you Love best? Tell me, or I'll beat you to Clouts, and Pinch thee like a Fary.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Believe me Sister, of all Men alive, I never saw that Particular Face which I cou'd Fancy more than another.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Huswife you Lye; and I could find in my Heart to Dash thy Teeth down thy Throat; I know thou Lov'st Goraldo.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: If you Affect him Sister, I Vow to plead for you my self, but you shall have him.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: O then belike you fancy Riches more, you Love Old VVoodall.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: That Old Fool: Nay now I see you but Jested with me all this while; I know you are not Angry with me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: If this be Jest, then all the rest is so: I'll make ye tell me e're I have done with you Gossip.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why now now Dame, Whence grows this Insolence? Biancha get thee in my Poor Girle; She Weeps; Fye, Peg, put off this Devillish Humour; Why dost thou Cross thy Tender Innocent Sister? When did she Cross thee with a Bitter Word?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Her Silence Flouts me, and I'll be Reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What in my sight too? You scurvy Ill-natur'd Thing: Go, poor Biancha, get thee out of her way.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: What will you not suffer me; nay, now I see she is your Treasure; She must have a Husband; and I Dance Bare-foot on her Wedding-Day: And for your Love to her, lead Apes in Hell. I see your care of me, I'll go and cry till I can find a way to be quit with her.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Was ever poor Man thus plagu'd?

div.stage: Enter Woodal with Winlove Disguis'd, with Jamy carrying a Lute and Books, and Tranio.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Sir your Servant, I am bold to wait on you to present you this Gentleman, an Acute teacher of the French Tongue, his Name's Mounsieur Mawgier, pray accept his service.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I am your debtor Sir, Mounsieur you'r wellcome.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Me give you humble thanks Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But what Gentleman is that?

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: I don't love him so well to tell you his Errant, but he wou'd come along with me, you had best ask him.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I beg you Pardon for my Intrusion, we heard your Fair and Virtuos Daughter Biancha, prais'd to such a height of Wonder, Fame has already made me her Servant; I've heard your Resolution not to Match her till her Eldest Sister be bestow'd, mean while I beg Admittance like the rest to keep my hopes alive; this Lute Sir, and these few French Romances I wou'd Dedicate to her Service.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir you oblige me, Pray your Name?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: 'Tis VVinlove, Son and Heir to Sir Lyonell VVinlove.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: My noble Friend, he has been my School-fellow; for his sake you are most kindly welcome, you shall have all the freedome I can give you.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Hand in hand, Sir, I'se go tell him my sel. Whare is this Laird?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Here, Sir, What wou'd you have, what are you?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Marry I'se can a bonny Scot, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: A Scotchman is that all?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Wun's wud ye have me a Cherub? I ha brought ye a small teaken Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But d'ye hear you Scot, don't you use to put off your Cap to your betters?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Marry we say in Scotland Gead Mourn til ye for aw the day, and sea put on our bonnets again, Sir; Bud Sir, I ha brought ye a Teaken.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To me, where is't; from whence is your Teaken?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Marry from my good Master Petruchio, Sir; he has sen ye a Piper to teach your Bonny Lasses to Pipe, but gin yet let Sauny teach 'em? I'se pipe 'em sea Whim—Whum, their Arses shall nere leave giging and joging while their's a Tooth in their head.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Petruchio! I remember him now, How does thy Master?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Marry Sir, he means to make one of your Lasses his Wanch, that is his Love and his Ligby.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You are a Sawcy Rogue.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud wull a Sir, he'll tak you Lass with a Long Tang that the Deel and Saundy wun a venter on, but he's here his aun sel, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Noble Petruchio welcome, I thank you for your kindness to my Daughters. Within there.

div.p: Conduct these Gentlemen to my Daughters, tell 'em these are both to be their Masters, bid 'em use 'em Civily; take in that Lute, and those Books there, Petruchio I hear you have lost your Father lately.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: 'Tis true, but I hope to find another in you; in short I hear you have a fair Daughter call'd Margaret, the World says she is a Shrew; But I think otherwise, you know my Fortune, if you like my Person, with your Consent, I'll be your Son-in-Law.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I have such a Daughter, but I so much Love you, I would not put her into your hands, she'll make you mad.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud he's as mad as heart can wish, Sir, he need nea halp, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I'll venture it Father, so I'll presume to call ye; I'm as Peremptory, as she's Proud-minded: and where two Rageing fires meet together they do consume the thing that feed's their fury; my Fathers Estate I have better'd, not Imbezell'd, then tell me, if I can get your Daughters Love, What Portion you will give?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: After my Death the Moiety of my Estate, and on the Wedding day Three Thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And I'll assure her Jointure answerable; get Writings drawn, I'll warrant you I'll carry the Wench.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Fair Luck betide you.

div.p: How now Man, What's the matter? Will my Daughter be a good Lutanist?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: She'll prove a better Cudgel Player, Lutes will not hold her.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why then thou canst not break her to thy Lute.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No, but she has broke the Lute to me; I did but tell her she mistook her fretts, and bow'd her head to teach her Fingrings, Fretts call you these, (quoth she) and I'll frett with you, so fairly took me o're the Pate with the Lute, and set me in the Pillory; and follow'd it with loud Volly's of Rogue, Rascal, Fidler, Jack, Puppy, and such like.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Now by the World I Love her ten times more than er'e I did.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud, bo the De'll a bit ye's wad her Sir, Wun's I'se nea gi twa Pence for my Luggs gin you make her yer Bride.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I'll warrant you Sauny, we'll deal with her well enough.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well Sir, I'll make you Reperation, proceed still with my youngest Daughter, she's apt to Learn; Petruchio will you go with us, or shall I send my Daughter to you?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Pray do Sir, and I'll attend her here.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud at ge gi Saundy a little Siller to gea to Scotland agen.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why Sauny, I have not us'd thee so unkindly.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud I'se nea tarry with a Scauding Quean Sir, yet the Dee'l faw my Luggs, if Ise ken which is worse, to tarry and venture my Cragg, or gea heam to Scotland.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Peace Sirrah, here she comes; now for a Rubbers at Cuffs. O Honey Pretty Peg, how do'st thou do Wench?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Marry come up Ragmanners, Plain Peg? Where were you bred? I am call'd Mrs. Margaret.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No, no, thou ly'st Peg, thou'rt call'd plain Peg, and Bonny Peg, and sometimes Peg the Curst, take this from me; Hearing thy Wildness prais'd in every Town, thy Virtues Sounded and thy Beauty spoke off: my self am mov'd to take thee for my Wife.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I knew at first you were a Moveable.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why what's a Moveable.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: A Joint Stool.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Thou hast hit it Peg, come sit upon me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Asses were made to bear, and so were you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why now I see the World has much abus'd thee, 'twas told me thou wert rough and Coy, and Sullen, but I do find thee pleasant, Mild and Curteous; Thou can'st not frown, nor Pout, nor bite the Lip as angry wenches do. Thou art all sweetness.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Do not Provoke me, I won't stand still and here my self abus'd.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What a Rogue was that told me thou wert Lame, thou art as streight as an Osier! and as Plyable, O what a rare walk's there! why there's a gate puts down the King of Frances best great Horse.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: And the King of Scotland's tea.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Where did'st thou Learn the grand Paw Peg? It becomes thee rarely.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Doe's it so sawcebox? how will a halter become you with a runing knot under one Ear?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, no knot Peg, but the knot of Matrimony 'twixt thee and me, we shall be an Excellent Mad Couple well match'd

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I match'd to thee? what to such a fellow with such a Gridiron face; with a Nose set on like a Candels end stuck against a Mud wall; and a Mouth to eat Milk Porridge with Ladles? Foh, it almost turns my Stomach to look on't.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud an your Stomach wamble to see his Face, What will ye dea when ye see his Arse Madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Marry come up Abberdeen, take that [hits him a box on the Ear.] and speak next when it comes to your turn.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed the Deel tak a gripe O yer faw fingers and Driss your Doublat for ye.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Take heed Peg, Sauny's a Desperate Fellow.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You'r a couple of Logger heads Master and Man, that I can tell you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Stay Peg, for all this I do like thee, and I mean to have thee, in truth I am thy Servant.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Aye you, why then I'll give you a favour, and thus I'll tye it on, there's for you.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Out, out, I'se gea for Scotland, Gud an she beat ye Saundy's a Dead Man.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I'll swear I'll cuff you, if you Strike agen.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: That's the way to loose your Armes, if you strike a Woman, you are no Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A Herald Peg? Prithee Blazon my Coat.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I know not your Coat, but your Crest is a Coxcombe.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Stop her Sirrah, stop her.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Let her gea her gate Sir, an e'n twa Deels and a Scotch wutch, blaw her weeme full of Wind.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Stay her Sirrah, stay her, I say.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed Sir, stay her yer sen, but hear ye Sir, an her tale gea as fast as her tang, Gud ye ha meet with a Whupster, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Prethee Peg stay, and I'll talk to thee in Earnest.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You may pump long enough er'e you get out a wise word, get a Night Cap to keep your brains warm.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I mean thou shalt keep me warm in thy Bed Peg, What think'st thou of that Peg? in plain terms without more ado I have your Fathers Consent, your Portions agreed upon, your Joynture settled, and for your own part, be willing or unwilling all's one, you I will marry, I am resolv'd on't.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Marry come up Jack a Lent, without my Leave?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A Rush for your Leave, here's a Clutter with a troublesom Woman, rest you contented, I'll have it so.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You shall be bak'd first, you shall; within there, ha!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Hold, get me a Stick there Sauny; by this hand, deny to Promise before your Father, I'll not Leave you a whole rib, I'll make you do't and be glad on't.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why you will not Murther me Sirrah? you are a couple of Rascals, I don't think, but you have pickt my Pockets.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: I'se sooner pick your tang out O' your head, nor pick your Pocket.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Come leave your idle prating, have you I will or no man ever shall, whoever else attempts it his throat will I Cut, before he lyes one night with thee, it may be thine too for company; I am the Man am born to tame thee Peg.

div.p: Here comes your Father, never make denial, if you do, you know what follows.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: The Devil's in this fellow, he has beat me at my own Weapon, I have a good mind to marry him to try if he can Tame me.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Now Petruchio, how speed you with my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: How but well, it were Impossible I shou'd speed amiss, 'tis the best Naturd'st Lady—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why how now Daughter, in your Dumps?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You shew a Fathers care indeed to Match me with this mad Hectoring Fellow.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: She has been abus'd Father, most unworthily, she is not Curst unless for Pollicy; for Patience, a second Grizel; betwixt us we have so agreed, the Wedding is to be on Thursday next.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud Saundy's gea for Scotland a Tuesday then.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Heark Petruchio, shee says shee'll see you hang'd first, is this your speeding? I shall make you refund.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Pish, that's but a way she has gotten, I have Wood her, Won her, and shee's my own; we have made a bargin that before Company she shall maintain a little of her Extravagant Humour, for she must not seem to fall off from't too soon; when we are alone, we are the kindest, Lovingst, tenderst Chickins to one another! Pray Father provide the Feast, and bid the Guests, I must home to settle some things, and fetch some Writings in order to her Joynture.—Farewel Gallants, give me thy hand Peg.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I knot not what to say, but give me your hands, send you Joy; Petruchio, 'tis a Match.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Tran. Amen say we, we all are Witnesses.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why Sir de'ye mean to Match me in spight of my Teeth?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, peace Peg, Peace, thou needst not be pevish before these, 'tis only before strangers according to our bargain; Come Peg, thou shalt go see me take horse, farewel Father.

sp.speaker: Marg
sp.p: As I live I will not.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: By this Light but you shall; nay, no testy tricks, away.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud I'se be your Lieutenant and bring up your reer Madam.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Was ever match clapt up so suddingly?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Faith Gentlemen, I have ventur'd madly on a Desperate Mart.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: But now Sir, as to your younger Daughter, you may remember my long Love and Service.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I hope I may (without Arrogance Sir,) beg you to look on me as a Person of more Merit.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Content ye Gentlemen, I'll compound this strife, 'tis Deeds not Words must win the Prize: I love you both, but he that can assure my Daughter the Noblest Joynture has her, What say you Sir?

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: I'll make it out my Estate is worth De clara, full Twenty Thousand Pounds, besides some ventures at Sea, and all I have, at my Discease I give her.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Is that all Sir? Alas 'tis too Light Sir, I am my Fathers Heir, and only Son, and his Estate is worth Three thousand pound per Annum; that will aford a Joynture answerable to her Portion; no Debts, nor Incumbrances, No Portions to be paid—have I nip't you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I must confess your offer is the best, and let your Father make her this assureance, she is your own, else you must pardon me, if you should dye before him, where's her Power?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: That's but a Cavel, hee's old, I young.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: And may not young men dye as well as old, have I nip't you there again?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, I am thus resolv'd, on Thursday my Daughter Peg is to be Married; the Thursday following Biancha's yours, if you make this Assurance; if not, Mr. Woodall has her; and so I take my Leave, and thank you both.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant; Now I fear you not: Alas, Young Man, your Father is not such a Fool, to give you all, and in his waining Age, set footing under your Table; You may go Whistle for your Mistriss▪ ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Tranio.
sp.p:
A Vengance on your Crafty Wither'd Hide. Yet 'tis in my head to do my Master good: I see no reason why this suppos'd young VVinlove should not get a suppos'd Father, call'd, Sir Lyonell VVinlove, and
that's a wonder, Fathers commonly get their Children, but here the Case must be alter'd.
sp.l: Love Brings such Prodigies as these to Town,
For that, at Best, turns all things upside Down.

div.head: ACT. III.
div.stage: Enter Winlove, Geraldo, Biancha. Table cover'd with Velvet, Two Chaires and Guitar. A Paper Prickt with SONGS.

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: PRay Madam, will you take out this Lesson on the Gittar.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Here be de ver sine Story in de Varle of Mounsieur Appollo, And Madomoselle Daphne; Me vill Read you dat Madam.

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: Good Madam, mind not that Monsieur Shorthose; But Learn this Lesson first.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Begar Monsieur Fideler, you be de vera fine troublesome Fellow, me vil make de great Hole in your Head wid de Gittar, as Margaret did.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: This is no Place to Quarrel in: But Remember—

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, you do me double wrong, to strive for that which Resteth in my Bare Choice: To end the Quarrel, sit down and Tune your Instrument, and by that time his Lecture will be done.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: You'l leave his Lecture, when I am in Tune.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Yes, yes; Pray be satisfied: Come, Monsieur, let's see your Ode.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: I do suspect that Fellow, Sure he's no Lute-Master.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Here's the Place, Come Read.

div.p: Do not Believe I am a Frenchman, my Name is VVinlove; He that bears my Name about the Town, is my Man Tranio. I am your passionate Servant, and must live by your Smiles. Therefore be so good, to give Life to my hopes.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Madam, your Gittar is in Tune.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Let's hear; fye, there's a String split.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Make de spit in the Whole Man, and Tune it again.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Now let me see. I know not how to believe you. But if it be true, Noble Mr. VVinlove deserves to be belov'd; and, in the mean time, keep your own Councell; and it is not impossible but your Hopes may be Converted into Certainties.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Madam, now 'tis Perfectly in Tune.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Fye, fye, Begar no Tune at all.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Mounsieur, Pray walk now, and give me leave a while, my Lesson will make no Musick in Three Parts.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Me vil no trouble you Mounsieur Fiddeller. I am confident it is so, this must be some Person that has taken a Disguise, like me, to Court Biancha; I'll watch him.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: First, Madam, be pleas'd to Sing the Last Song that I Taught you, and then we'll proceed.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: I'll try, but I'm afraid I shall be out.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Madam, before you proceed any farther, there be some few Rules set down in this Paper, in order to your Fingering, will be worth your Perusal.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Let's see.

div.p: Tho' I appear a Lute-Master, yet know my fair Biancha, I have but taken this disguise to get Access to you, and tell you I am your humble Servant, and Passionate Admirer, Geraldo. Pish, take your Rules again, I like 'em not the old way pleases me best, I do not care for changing old Rules, for these Foolish new Inventions.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam my Lord calls for you to help dress the Bride.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Farewell then Master, I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I know not what to think of her, this fellow looks, as if he were in Love, and she carresses him. These damn'd French men, have got all the trade in Town, if they get up all the handsome Women, the English must e'en march into Wales for Mistersses; well, if thy thoughts Biancha are grown so low, to cast thy wandring Eyes on such a kikshaw, I'me resolv'd to ply my Widow.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I am glad I'me rid of him, that I may speak my Mother Tongue agen, Biancha has given me hopes, I dare half believe she Loves me.

div.stage: Enter Beaufoy, Woodal, Tranio, Margaret, Biancha, and Attendants

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Believe me Gentlemen, 'tis very strange! This day Petruchio appointed, yet he comes not; methinks he shou'd be more a Gentleman, then to put such a slur upon my Family.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Nay, you have us'd me sinely, and like a Father; I must be forc'd to give my hand against my will, to a rude mad brain'd Fellow here; who Woo'd in hast, and means to Wed at Leisure. this comes of obeying you, if I do't again, were you ten thousand Fathers hang me.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Be Patient Madam, on my life hee'll come; though he be blunt and merry, I'm sure hee's Noble; good Madam, go put on your Wedding Cloaths, I know he'll be with you e're you be Drest.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Wedding Cloaths, I'll see him hang'd before I'll have him, unless it be to scratch his Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Poor Girl! I cannot blame thee now to weep, for such an Injury wou'd vex a Saint; Tho I am old, I shall find some body will call him to a strict Account for this.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: O Master, News! News! and such News as you never heard off.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why what News have you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Is't not News to hear of Petruchio's Coming?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why, is he come?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Why, no my Lord.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What then Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: He's coming Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: When will he be here?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: When he stands where I am and sees you there.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well sarrah, is this all the News?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Why Petruchio is coming in a new Hat, and an old Jerkin, a pair of Britches thrice turn'd, a pair of Boots that have been Candle-cases; an old rusty Sword with a broken hilt, and never a Chape, upon an old Lean, Lame, Spavin'd, Glander'd, Broken-winded Jade, with a Womans Crupper of Velvit, here and there peec'd with packthreed.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Who comes with him?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: O Sir, his Man Sauny, and in an Equippage very suitable to his Master, he looks no more like a Christian Footman, then I look like a Windmill.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: This is a most strange Extravagant Humour.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I'me glad he comes however he be!

div.stage: Enter Petruchio and Sauny strangely Habbited.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Come, Where be these Gallants, who's at home?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You're Wellcome Sir, I'm glad you're come at last.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I think I have seen you in better Cloathes.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Never, never, Sir, this is my Wedding Suite; Why how now, how now Gentlemen, What d'ye stare at, d'ye take me for a Monster?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Faith in that Habit you might pass for one in the Fair.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: O you talk merrily, my Taylor tells me it is the newest Fashion: But where's my Peg? I stay too long from her, the Morning wear's, 'tis time we were at Church.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Why you won't Visit her thus.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Marry but I will.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: And sea will Saundy tea Sir.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But you will not Marry her so will you?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: A my Saul sal he Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: To me shee's Married, not to my Cloathes; Will ye along Father and Gentlemen? I'll to Church imediately, not tarry a minute.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Here ye Sir, ye sal Marry her after the Scotch Directory, then gin ye like her not, ye maw put her awaw, How say ye now?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: He has some meaning in this mad Attire, but you must perswade him to put on a better, e're he goes to Church

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Let's after and see what will become of it.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Well Sir, you find there's no other way, 'tis too short warning to get your Father up; shou'd you Steal the Match, who knows but both the old Fools wou'd so deeply resent it to your Prejudice.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Why Prethee this way it will be Stolen for 'tis but a Cheat, which will be in a little time Discover'd.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: That's all one, it Carries a better face, and we shall have the more sport; besides e're it comes out, your Father may be wrought to like it, and Confirm my Promises; She is suitable to you every way, and she is rich enough to do it, and Loves you well enough besides.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Well if it must be so, let's contrive it handsomly.

sp.speaker: Tran▪
sp.p: Let me alone, Iamy shall do the business, he shall find out some Knight of the Post, that shall be old Sir Lyonel VVinlove here, and make Assurance of a greater Joynture then I propos'd; ne're fear it Sir, I'll so Instruct him, it shall be carryed without the least Suspition.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Ay but you know old Beaufoy knows my Father.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: That's nothing, 'tis so many years since he saw him, he will never distinguish him by his face.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: This may be done, but notwithstanding all did not my fellow Teacher, that damn'd Lute-master so nearly watch us, 'twou'd not be amiss to steal a Marriage, and that once perform'd, let all the World say no, I'll keep my own.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: That we may think on too; this same Lute-Master I more then half suspect.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: And so do I.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I have mist a Gentleman out of the gang a good while, but let that pass, I have already sent Iamy to find a Man.

div.p: To our postures, here's Mr. VVoodall, he must be Chous'd too among the rest, save you Sir, Came you from the Church?

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: As willingly as e're I came from Schoole.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: And is the Bride and Bridegroome coming home.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: A Bridegroome, why hee's a Bridegroome for the Devil, a Devil, a very Fiend.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Why shee's a Devil, an errant Devil; nay, the Devils Dam.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: But shee's a Lamb, a Dove, a Child to him: When the Priest askt if he would take Margaret for his Wife, I by Gogs wound's quoth he, and Swore so loud! that all amaz'd, the Priest lets fall the Book, and as the Sexton stoop'd to take it up, this mad brain'd Bridegroome took him such a cuff, that down fell Sexton Book and all again; now take it up quoth he if any list.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: What said the poor Bride to this?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Trembl'd and shook like an Aspen Leafe; after this just as the Parson joyn'd their hands, he call'd to his Roguy Scotchman, for a Glass of Muscadine, drank his Wives Health, and threw the Toast in the Clarks face, because his Beard grew thin and hungry, then took the Bride about the Neck and gave her such a Smack the Church eccho'd again; the sight of this made me run away for shame, I know they are following by this time; but hark, I hear the Minstrels. Musick.

div.stage: Enter Beaufoy, Petruchio, Margaret, Biancha, Geraldo, Sauny, &c.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Friends I thank you for your Pains, I know you think to Dine with me to day, and have prepar'd great store of Wedding Chear, but so it is, grand business calls me hence, and I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is't Possible you will away to night?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I must immediately, if you knew my business you wou'd not wonder; well honest Gentlemen I thank you all, that have beheld me give away my self to this most Patient, Sweet and virtuous Wife; Dine with my Father here, and drink my health for I must hence, so farewel to you all.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Wun's will ye nea eat your Wadden Dunner, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Let us Intreat you to stay till after Dinner.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: It must not be.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Let me Intreat you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: That will do much, I am Content.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Are you content to stay?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I am content you shou'd Intreat me, but yet I will not stay intreat me how you can.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Now if you Love me stay.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I cannot, Sauny the Horses.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: They have nea ea't their Wadden Dunner yet.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sirrah get the Horses.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Nay then do what thou canst, I wont go to day, nor to morrow, nor till I please my self. The door is open Sir, there lyes your way, you may be jogging while your boots be green.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: O Peg content thee, Prithee be not angry.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I will be angry, What hast thou to do? Father he quiet, he shall stay my Leisure.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I marry Sir, now it begins to Work.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Gentlemen forward to the Bridal Dinner; I see a Woman may be made a fool off, if she want Spirit to resist.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: They shall go forward Peg at thy Command; Obey the Bride you that attend on her. Go to the Feast, Revel, Carouse, and Dance▪ be Mad or Merry, or go hang your selves, but for my Bonny Peg shee must with me; Nay look not big uppn't, nor stamp, nor stair, nor fret; Come, come, gently, so so, so, that's my good Peg, I will be master of my own; She is my proper goods and Chattells; my House, my Ox, my Ass, my any thing: Look here she stands, touch her who dare, I'll make him smoak that offers to stop me in my way. Sauny unsheath thy Dudgeon Dagger, we are beset with Thieves, rescue thy Mistriss if thou beest a Man; fear not sweet Wench I'll Buckler thee against a Million; nay, come.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Will none of you help me?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: The Deel a bit of Dunner ye gat, Gud at ye woud speak to your Cuke to gi Saundy a little Mutton and Porridge to put in his Wallet.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay let 'em go, a couple of quiet ones.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Never was so mad a Match.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen let's in, we have a Dinner, although we want a Bride and Bridegroome to it; Biancha you shall take your Sisters Roome, and Mr. Winlove you may Practise for a Bridegroome.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Mounsieur how do ye find my Mistress inclin'd?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Me can no tell dat yet, but in time Mounsieur sal inform you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Pray Ply her close, here's something for you.

sp.speaker: Win,
sp.p: Me tank you, Sir; Ha, ha, ha, I must go tell this to my Biancha.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Hark ye Sir, you may inform me, Pray what think you, does Madam Biancha fancy any other but my self, she bears me fair in hand, pray discover Sir, I shall not be ungrateful?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Troth Sir, I think shee's as all other Women are.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: How is that pray?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Why Fickle and Foolish.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Why d' ye think so of her, shee was always held Discreet?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No sober Man will think so, I tell you Sir, shee cares neither for you, nor any Man, that's worth careing for; shee's falne in Love with a Mounsier Jack-daw, a fellow that teaches bad French, in worse English.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: That fellow, why 'tis impossible.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: 'Tis true tho'.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Why I am confident he was employ'd by old Woodall as his Instrument to Court her for him.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: If he were, he has spoken one word for him and two for himself.

div.p: See here they come hand in hand, stand close, perhaps your Eyes may convince you.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Madam, you need not doubt my Passion; by those fair Eyes I swear (an Oath inviolable) you have made a Conquest over me so absolute, that I must dye your Captive.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: What does he say, what does he say?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I cannot hear, Listen.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: I must believe you Sir, there's some strange power attends your Words, your Attractive Actions, and your Person, which is too strong for my weak resistance; you have won, but do not boast your Victory.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Nay then I see 'tis so, I cannot hold! Madam you must forgive my Interruption, you have us'd me kindly, fool'd me with fine hopes, your Mounsieur there has read Excellent Lessons to you.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Sir, I understand you not.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: That is, you won't.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: What be de matter Mounsieur Fiddeler?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: No Fiddler, nor no Lutanist Mounsieur, No point, but one that scorns to live in a Disguise; for such a one as leaves a Gentleman, to doat upon a Pardon a moy Jack-pudding; know, I am a Gentleman, my name Geraldo.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Alas, Sir, And have you been my Master all this while, and I never knew it?

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: Yes, Sweet Lady, you did know it; I see you have a Little Spice of Peg in you: But I have done with you, Mr. Winlove; Pray tell me, Don't you hate this Gentlewoman now?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: I cannot say I Hate her; but I'm sure I don't Love her for this days Work, Wou'd she Court me, I Swear I wou'd not have her.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Nor I, by Heavens: I have Sworn, and will keep my Oath.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Why Gentlemen, I hope you will not both give the Willow Garland.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Go, go, you are a Scurvy Woman; I have a Widdow that has Lov'd me as Long as I have Lov'd you. Sweet Lady, I am not Bankrupt for a Mistriss: 'Tis true, she's something of your Sisters Humour, a Little Way-ward: but one Three Dayes time at the Taming-Schoole, will make her Vye with any Wife in England. And then I can pass by you unconcern'd.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: The Taming-School, for Heavens-sake where is that Sir?

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Why your Brother Petruchio's House: I doubt you must there too, e're you'll be good for any thing; I'll to him immediately? Farewell thou Vile Woman.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, this is Excellent.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Madam, I beg your Pardon; but I hope my boldness with you, has done my Master some Service.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Believe me has it Tranio, and I must thank thee.

div.p: Now, Sirrah, Whither away in such hast?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: O Master, I have found him.

sp.speaker: Winl.
sp.p: What? Who hast thou found?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: A rare old Sinner in the Temple Cloysters will do the Feat to a hair.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: What feat? What's to be done?

sp.speaker: Winl.
sp.l: That which I told you of my Fairest:
Where is he?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Here, here, he Walks in the Court.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.l: Well, I must in, or I shall be mist;
Carry the Matter handsomly, and let me not suffer.

sp.speaker: Winl.
sp.l: Fear not Madam; Call him in, Tranio
You must Instruct him, I'll not be seen in't.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Now Friend, What are you?

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: Any thing that you please Sir.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Any thing; Why what can you do.

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: Any thing, for so much as Concerns Swearing and Lying to your Worships Service, and to get an Honest Livelyhood, So please you to Imploy me.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.l: Why thou may'st serve turn I think;
But I'll put thee to no Swearing, Bare Lying and Impudence will serve for my Occasion;
You must bate of the Price for that.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, they'r both of a Price, take e'm or leave e'm.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: But canst thou Mannage and Carry off a good Well-contriv'd Lye, to the best advantage?

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: I should be very sorry else; it has been my Trade these Seven and thirty Years, never fear it Sir.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.l: Nay, I pickt him out amongst half a Score;
I fancy'd he had the best Lying Face amongst e'm.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Well, come along with me, and I'll Instruct you; But if you fail, look to your Eares, if you have any.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: I'll venture Neck and all to do it Sir.

div.stage: Enter Sauny and Curtis severally. Petruchio's House.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Honest Sauny, Wellcome, wellcome.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Saundy's Hungry; Can't you get a little Meat, Sir?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, Sawny.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Ye mun gat a gude Fire, Sir; Mrs. Bride has gat a faw intull a Dike, She's aw wet Sir; Gud she has not a dry thread to her Arse.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Is Master and Mistriss coming Sauny?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud are they, gin they be nea frozen to the grund, bo whare's your Fire man?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: 'Tis making, 'tis making, all things are ready; Prithee what News good Sauny, what kind of Woman is our Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Ken ye twa twanty Deel's Sir.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Marry Heaven defend us.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud shee has ean twa twanty Deel's I'se nea bate ye can of 'em.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: They say shee's a Cruel Shrew.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: O my saul Sir, I'se hau'd a thousand pund, shee's set up her Tang, and Scaud fro Edingbrough to London, and nere draw bit for't.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: What shall we do then, there will be no living for us.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud will there not, Wun's I think the Deel has flead off her Skin, and put his Dam intul't; Bo where's Phillip and George and Gregory.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: They'r all ready, what ho, come forth here, Phillip, George, Ioseph, Nick, where are you?

sp.speaker: Phillp.
sp.p: Honest Sawny, Wellcome home.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gat me some Meat, and I'll believe ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: I am glad to see thee Sawny.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gat me a Drink, and Is'e believe ye tea.

sp.speaker: Iosep.
sp.p: What, Sawny come to Town again, Wellcome?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Wun's, Walcome, walcome, gat me gude Meat and Drink, that is Walcome, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Old Lusty Fellow Sawny, Wellcome.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: How d'ye Wully?

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: D'ye hear the News, Sawny? Wally Watts is Dead.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed, nea Man that geas on twa Leggs cou'd slay Wully Watts, Sir.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: True; for he was fairly Hang'd.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: I was sure nea Man that went on twa Leggs could slay him.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: You are in the right Sawny, for 'twas one with Three Leggs, 'twas Mr. Tyburne, for he was fairly Hang'd.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed ye Lye, Sir, the Gallows might kill him, and break his stout heart, but it cou'd nea hang him: 'Tis hang an English Man.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Well, But what kind of Woman is our Mistriss, Sawny.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: You'l ken soon enough 'tea your Sorrow, and wea Sir; Ye've awe twa Luggs apeece o'your Head: A my Saul I'se nea gea ye twa Pennys for them by'th Morn: How say ye now?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Where be these Idle Rogues? What no more at Door to hold my Stirrip, or take my Horses? Where's Curtis, Phillip, Nick and Gregory?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Here, Here, Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Here, here, here, you Loggerhead Currs; What, no Attendance, no Regard, no Duty? Where's that Foolish Knave I sent before.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Wuns, Sir, Ise be sea hungry, snd sea empty, ye may travell quite through me, and nere faw your fingers Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You Mangy Rogue, Did not I bid you meet me in the Park, and bring these Rascals with you?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud did ye Sir; bo Ise sea hungry, Ise ha nea Memory, Deliver your Message your sel Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Be gone you Slaves, and fetch my Supper in; Rogues do I speak, and don't you fly to make hast. [Exit 2 or 3 Servants. Sit down Peg and Wellcome. Why when I Pray, nay good sweet Peg be Merry, These are Country Clownish Fellows; Prithee be Merry: Off with my Bootes, Sirrah, you Rogues, ye Villaius. When
sp.l: It was the Orders of the Fryar Gray,
As forth he walked on his Way.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Sure he will run himself out of Breath, and then it will be my turn.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: Out you Rogue; You pluck my Boot awry; take that, and mend it in pulling off the other. Be Merry Peg. Some Water here, ho; VVhere's my Spanniel, Sarrah? Make hast and desire my Cousin Ferdinand to come hither, one Peg you must Kiss, and be Acquainted with: VVhere are my Slippers? Shall I have some VVater. Come, Peg, wash and VVellcome Heartily.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: VVuns bo whare is the Meat to mack her Vvelcome.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: VVe shall fall out if we wash together.

sp.speaker: Petru.
sp.p: You VVhorson Villain will you let it fall?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Pray Sir be Patient, 'twas an unwilling Fault.

div.stage: Table Cover'd. Enter Servants with Meat.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: An Idle, Careless, Beetle-headed-Slave.
Come, Peg, sit down. I know you have a Stomach.
VVill you give Thanks, Sweet Peg, or shall I?
Or each for our selves? Come, fall too,
VVhat's this, Mutton?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud it is, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: VVho bought it?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I did Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You Rascal you 'tis not Mutton, 'tis the Breast of a Dog; What Currs are these? 'tis dry'd and burn't to a Coal too, Where is this Rascal Cook? How dare you bring such rotten Meat to my Table? Why d' ye mean to Poyson me, ye heedless Joltheads? ye ill manner'd Whelps, what d' ye grumble? I'll be with you straight.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Pray Husband be content, the Meat is good Meat; and I am very hungry, I must and will eat some of it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Not for the World Peg, I Love thee better then so; 'Tis burnt and will Ingender Chollar, a Disease we are both to Subject too; I Love thee too well to give thee any thing to hurt thee, we'll fast to night, to morrow we'll make it up.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Say what you will Sir, I'll eat some of it; Did you bring me hither to Starve me?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why ye Rascals will ye stand Still and see your Mistriss Poyson her self? take it away out of her sight, quickly.

div.stage: [Throws the Meat at 'em, Sauny gets it.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud Saundy will venture, Poyson and 'twill.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well Peg, this night we'll fast for Company; Come I'll bring thee to the Bridall Chamber.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I must Eat something, I shall be Sick else; But an Egg.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No, no, Prithee dont talk on't; to Bed upon a full stomach.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: But a Crust of Bread.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: To morrow, to morrow; Come prithee away.

sp.speaker: Geor.
sp.p: Did'st ever see the like?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: He kills her in her own Humour.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Have you said Grace Sauny?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud I was sea hungry, I forgot Grace. O thou that hast fill'd our Boyes, and our blathers, keep us aw from Whoredome, and Secrisie.

sp.speaker: Nick.
sp.p: Secrecy, why Sauny?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Wuns Man, it is wutchcraft, peace, you put me out with the Deel's name to ye: Keep us aw from Whoredome and Secresie, fro the Dinger o' the swatch to the gallow Tree, keep us aw we Beseech thee; Tak a Drink man.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Are ye full now Sauny?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: As for as a Piper, ye may put can finger in at my Mouth, and another in mine Arse, and feel beath ends o' my Dinner.

div.stage: Enter as in a Bed-Chamber, Petruchio, Peg, and Servants, Sauny.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Where are you, you Rogues? Some lights there, come Peg undress to bed, to bed.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Pray send your Men away, and call for some of your Maids.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Maids, hang Maids, I have no such vermine about my house, any of
these will do as well; Here Sauny come hither Sirrah, and undress your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: O my Saul Sir, I'se put on my head-peice; now, an ye'll bind her hands behind her, I'se undress her.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What dost thou do?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: In Scotland we aw wayes begin at the nether end of a bonny Lass.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Who made this Bed? What Rascals are these? Foh these Sheets are Musty as the Devil, and what Rags are here upon my Bed? Is this a Counterpain? 'tis a Dishclout.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why the Counterpain is well enough, and Rich enough, and the Sheet's are as Clean, and as Sweet as may be.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Fye, fye Peg, thou hast got a Cold, and lost thy Smelling, I tell thee they are all Damp and Musty, I wou'd not have thee to venture to Lye in 'em for the world, it wou'd be thy Death; here take 'em away, we must ce'n sit up, there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Pray Sir talk not of sitting up, I am so sleepy I cant hold my Eyes open, I must to Bed.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I'll keep thee waking, I warrant thee; Ho Curtis bring us a Flaggon of March Beer, and some Tobacco, and clean Pipes, we'll be merry.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why what d' ye mean are you Mad?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Mad? I, what should we do? I mean thou and I hand to fist, will drink a Health to my Father, and my Sister, and all our good Friends at London.

div.stage: Enter Servant with Beer and Tobacco.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why you dont take me to be one of your fellow Tospots?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I mean to Teach thee to Drink; thou must Learn that, or thou'rt no Wife for me: Here, Peg, to thee with all my Heart, a whole one, and thou art Wellcome; My Father's good Health, Peg, you shall Pledge it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I can't Drink without Eating; 'twill make me sick.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Pish, Pish, that's but a Fancy; Come, off with it, or thou shalt neither eat nor drink this Month.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Shall I go to Bed when I have drank it?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud at ye gi Sawndy a little Drink Madam.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.l: Talk of that anon.
So, here Peg, heres a Pipe I have fill'd for thee my self,
Sit down, and Light it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: D'ye mean to make a meer Hackny Horse of me? What d'offer me your nasty Tobacco for?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, ne're make so shy, I know' thou Lov'st it: Come, young Ladies are often troubled with the Tooth-ach, and take it in their Chambers, though they won't appear Good Fellows amongst us: Take it, or no Sleep nor Meat, Peg, D'ye hear.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yes, to my Griefe; I won't be abus'd thus.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, nay, Goe where thou wilt, I'll make thee Smoak before I Sleep.

div.head: ACT. IV.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: SIrrah, wait on your Mistriss; Say what you will to her, and Vex her, but do not touch her; and let her have no Meat I Charge ye.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed Sir, send her into the Highlands in Scotland, there's Hunger and Caud enough, there she may starve her Bally foo.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well Sirrah, Doe as I direct you.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: O' my Saul wull I Sir, Yee'l let me take my Head-piece to defend me Sir.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: What Gregory, Phillip! No Body near me? Sawny, Where are you?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Is'e een hard at your Arse Madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Where's your Master?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: He's gone to the Market himself, and he'l bring ye heam a Braw Bull's Puzzle to Swaddle your Weam with.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: And in the mean time I am Famisht; Was ever Woman us'd so Damnably? I am Starv'd for Meat, Giddy for want of Sleep; and that which Spites me more then all the rest, is, he pretends 'tis out of Care and Love to me: Prithee good Sawny give me some Meat.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: O' my Saul, Sawndy wou'd be Hang'd gin I sud bestow an aw'd Liquor'd Bute, Sawny will cut it into Tripes to Stuff your Weam with.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Good Sawny, here's Money for thee, but one little bit of any thing to stay my fainting Spirits.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: What will ye eat a Bit of Beefe?

sp.speaker: Marg,
sp.p: I, good Sawny.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Will ye eat some Mustard to't?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: I, good Sawny, quickly.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Mustard is nea gu'd for your Tang, 'twill make it tea keen, and ye can Scau'd fast enough without.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why then the Beef without Mustard.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud Beef is nee gued without Mustard: Sawny will fetch ye some Meal and Water, ye'st make ye a Scotch Pudding, ye'st Eat of that tull your Weam crack.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You Abusive Rogue take that,
Must I be Brav'd thus by my own Servant.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: The Dee'l wash your Face with a Fou Clout.

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: Why how now, Sirrah, VVill you strike your Mistriss? You Cowardly Rogue strike a VVoman.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed Sir, D'ye Caw a Scotchman a Coward? Gin Is'e had ye in Scotland, Is'e put my Whinyard in your Weam, gin ye were as stout as Gilderoy.

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: VVhy Gilderoy was as arrant a Coward as thou art.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: VVuns yeed be lath to keep the Grund that Gilderoy quits; yet I must confess he was a little Shame-fac'd before the Enemy.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: O Mr. Geraldo, never was Poor VVoman so us'd. For Charity sake Convey me home to my Father.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio with a Dish of Meat.

sp.speaker: Petru.
Marg.
sp.p: VVhy 'tis a Pullet.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: VVhy 'tis Veal, Art thou Mad?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You won't Perswade me out of my Sences,
'Tis a Pullet.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: A Gud is it Sir.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: VVhat an unhappy Man am I, my poor Dear Peg's Distracted. I always fear'd 'twould come to this. Take the Meat away Curtis; Is the Room Ready as I Order'd? Are the Lights Damn'd up?

sp.speaker: Curtis.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: VVhy what d'ye mean to do with me?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Poor Peg, I Pitty thee; but thou shalt want no Help for thy Cure, you must be kept from the Light, it troubles the Brain.

sp.speaker: Cer.
sp.p: I see I shall Learn, he's an Excellent Teacher.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: VVhy Sir, Pray tell me, Have you a mind to make me Mad? this is the way indeed: How have I injur'd you, that you use me thus inhumanely? Did you Marry me to starve me?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: He means to bring down your VVeam for a Race; For we awways Cry a Nag with a VVeam, but a Mare with Nean.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No, no; Good Peg thou know'st I have a Care of thee; Here's a Gown just brought home for thee Peg. Now thou art empty, it will sit Handsomely; VVhere is this Taylor? Call him in Sawny, if it fits you, you shall put it on, and wee'l Gallop o're to London, and see your Father; Your Sisters VVedding is at hand, you must help her.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: If she be Match'd as I am, Heaven help her! But there's some Comfort in going Home; there's Meat and Sleeping-room.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Come Taylor, lets see the Gowne, How now what's here? Bless me, what Masquing Suite is this! What's this a Sleve? why 'tis like a Demmy Cannon, Why what a Devil Taylor dost thou mean? Is this a Gown?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: A gown Sir? yes Sir, and a handsome Gown as any Man in London can make, 'tis the newest Fashon lately come out of France.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What a lying knave art thou! my great Grand-mothers Picture in the Matted Gallery is just such another.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: It is like the Picture of Queen Margaret in Edenbrough Castle, Sir.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I never saw a better Fashon'd Gown in my life; more quaint nor better shap'd, I like the Gown, and I'll have this Gown or I'll have none; say what you will I like it, 'tis a handsom Gown.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why thou sayst true Peg, 'tis an ugly paltrey Gown, I am glad to hear thee of my mind; 'tis a beastly Gown.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why I say 'tis a good Gown, a handsome fashionable Gown; What d'ye mean to make a Puppet of me?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ay, this fellow wou'd make a Puppet of thee?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: She says your Worship means to make a Puppet of her.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Thou Impudent, lying, Threed, Bodkin and Thimble, Flea, thou nit, brave me in my own house? Go take it, I'll ha none on't.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: Sir I made it according to your Directions, and I cannot take it again.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Tak it awaw, or the Deel O my Luggs, but yest tak my Whineyard.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: He shall not take it agen, what need you trouble your self about it, as long as it pleases me; lay it down there.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Sirrah take it away I say, we shall find more Taylors; I wont have my Wife so Antickly drest, that the Boys shoud hoot at her.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Come, come, all this is but fooling, you dont understand what belongs to a Gown, say what you will I'm resolv'd to have it, if it were an ugly one I wou'd wear it, and it were but to Cross you.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Now the Deel's a cruppen untell her Mouth Sir, you may see a little of his Tail hang out, it looks for aw the world an it were a Sting Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why that's my good Peg, I know thou dost not care for it; say no more prithee, thou shalt have another.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I know not what you mean to do with me, but methinks I might have leave to speak, and speak I will, I am no Child, no Baby; your Betters have endur'd me to speak my mind, and if you cannot you had best stop your Ears; 'Tis better set my Tongue at Liberty, then lee my Heart break.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Speak Peg, by all means, say what thou wilt; Sirrah carry that tawdry thing away, Ceraldo tell him you'll see him paid, [Aside.] and bid him leave it. Come what sayst thou Peg?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Leave the Gown in the next Room Taylor, and take no notice of what he says, I'll see you paid for't.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p:
Why I say I will have that Gown, and every thing I have a mind
〈…〉 not bring you such a Portion to be made a Fool of.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Very true, thou'rt in the right Peg; come lets to Horse, these Cloaths will serve turn at present till we can get better. Go Sirrah lead the Horses to the Lands end, thether we'll walk a foot; lets see, I think 'tis about seven a Clock, we shall reach to my Father in Laws by Dinner time with Ease.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: 'Tis almost Two, you cannot get thether by Supper time.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: It shall be seaven e're I go, why what a Mischief's this, what I say or do, you are still crossing it; Let the Horses alone, I will not go to day, and e're I do it shall be what a Clock I please.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Nay Sir, that shant stop our Journey, 'tis seaven, or two or nine, or what a Clock you please, pray lets go.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Ye's have it what hour you wull Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Very well it is so, get ready quickly; Come Geraldo let's all go, we shall help mend the Mirth at my Sisters Wedding.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I'll wait on you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Come Peg, get on your things.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Let me but once see Lincolns-Inn-Fields agen, and Yet thou shalt not Tame me.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Now Sirrah, be but Impudent enough and keep state like the old Knight, and thou art made for ever.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: I warrant ye Sir, I know it to a hair, my Lord Beaufoy and I were School fellows together at Worster; my Estate lyes in the Vale of Evesham, Three thousand Pound a year, and Fifteen hundred a year I settle upon you upon the Marriage, let me alone I am Sir Lyonell himself.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Right, right; Excellent brave, How now.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: To your Postures old Sinner, be an exquesite Rascal, and then thou shalt be a Rogue Paramount; thou shalt lay the Dragon asleep while my Master steals the Pippins.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Well Iamy, What hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: I have been with my Lord Beaufoy, presented your Fathers, and your Service to him, and told him the old Knight was happily come to Town, and hearing of your Love to Biancha, was so overjoy'd, he would Settle all upon you.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Well, and what said he?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: He gave me a Peece for my News, I told him Sir Lyonell desired his Company just now to treat upon the Match; he's coming in all hast, he longs to be Couzend, and Snatchpenny if thou dost not do it.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: Then hang me.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Mum look to't, he's here.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Mr. Winlove your Man tells me your Father is just happily come to Town▪ Where is he?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Here Sir, this is my Father; Time has been too Bold to weare ye out of each others Memory.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: Is this my Lord Beaufoy, Sir?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: My Lord your humble Servant; I'm happy at last to meet a Person I have formerly so much Lov'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Noble Sir Lyonell I joy to see you.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: O the merry Days that you and I have seen my Lord; Well fare the good old times I say.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I Sir Lyonell, when you and I were acquainted first.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: I marry, there were Golden Days, indeed, no Couzening, no Cheating, the World is alter'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But we will remember these times, and be honest still.
