sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: That's een the best way, there's hopes we may have honest Grand Children too, if all be true as I hear, my Son tells me, your Daughter has made a Captive of him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I wou'd she were better for his sake, she's a good Girle, and a handsome one, though I say it; if she were not, I wou'd give her somewhat shou'd make her so.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: It takes Rarely.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: I'm even overjoy'd that you think my Son worthy your Allyance, I'll give something they shall make a shift to Live on; in Plain and in breif, if you'll approve of it, I'll settle Fifteen hundred Pound a year upon him at Present, which shall be her Joynture; after my Death, all I have with a good will, What say you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir Lyonell, Your Freedome pleas's me; I see you are an honest meaning Gentleman: The Young Folks (if I am not mistaken) like one another. VVell, I say no more, it is a Match.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: You bind me to you Ever: Now I may boldly say, I am truly happy: VVhere will you please to have the business made up?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Not in my House, Son; I wou'd have it Private; Pitchers have Eares, and I have many Servants; Besides, Old VVoodall will be hindring of us; He's hearkening still, and will be interrupting.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Then at my Lodging; there my Father Lyes, and there the Business may be all Dispatch'd: Send for your Daughter by this Gentleman; my Boy shall fetch a Scrivener presently. The worst on't is, 'tis too small a VVarning. You are like to have but slender Entertainment.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: No matter, no matter; I shall like it.

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: I wou'd feign see your Daughter, my Lord; I have heard great Commendations of her.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That you shall presently; Mounsier, pray go to Biancha, and tell her from me, She must come hither with you immediately; you may tell her too, if you will, what has hapned, and that she must prepare to be A • r. VVinlove's Bride.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: My Lord, me vil fetch her presant.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: My Lord, VVill your Lordship please to walk in with my Father, this is my Lodging.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: I Sir; Come Sir Lyonell, I'll follow you.

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: Good my Lord, I will wait upon you.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Thus far 'tis well Carry'd on Iamy; But how shall we prosecute it?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: VVhy there is but one way in the VVorld, Sir.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: And what's that?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: VVhy thus, I have got a Parson ready for the Purpose; when you have got Biancha abroad, whip her into Covent-Garden Church, and there Marry her, and your VVork's done.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Troth thou say'st true; But is the Parson Orthodox and Canonical? I wou'd not have an Obadiah to make us enter into Covenant of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Trust me Sir, he's as true as Steel; he says all Matrimony without Book; he can Christen, Wed, and Bury Blindfold.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Well, I'll take thy Counsel, if I can perswade her to't, as I hope I shall, for I know she Loves me; fair Luck betides me; But who comes here.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: 'Tis the Olp Grub VVoodall; What shall we do with him?

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: We must contrive some way to get him off.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: I don't like those shuffling matters; I doubt there's some false Play towards me in hand: Here's my Monsieur he may Informe me— Mounsieur.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Che Dict a vouz Mounsieur. Mounsieur, Your Servant.

sp.speaker: VVood. Mounsieur,
sp.p: Prithee tell me, if thou canst, how Affaires go, things are carry'd very closely; How stands my Mistriss affected?

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Moy foy Mounsieur; Me tell you de bad News in the Varle, Madamoselle Biancha no stand Affected to you at all. My Lord has sent me to fetch her just now to be Marry to Mounsieur Vat you call? Mounsieur Le—

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: What not to VVinlove

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Yes to Mounsieur VVinlove; Begar me be very sorry, but me canno help dat.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Is Old Beaufoy mad to Match her to him without his Father's Privity.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Here be de ver Fine Old Man new come to Town, me Lord be wid him now.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Upon my Life old Sir Lyonell, nay then she's lost quite; Hark you Mounsier, yet 'tis in your Power to make me a happy Man.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: O Mounsier me be your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Why look you, you are to fetch her; here's forty Pound in Gold to buy you a pair of Gloves, let me take her from you, as you are carrying her thither; I will have two or three with me, and you may saftly say she was forc'd from you.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Mounsier begarr, me do you all de Service in the Varle, but me sal be the grand, Sheat Knave then.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: That's nothing, here's more Money, I'll save you harmless; Come, you shall do it.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Mounsier me have no mind to be van Knave, but to do you Service, if you will meet me upon de Street.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Fear not I'll secure you, honest Mounsieur farewell; I will be your Friend for Ever.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, this is rare; What an Ass this Fellow will make himself, do what we can? Here Iamy, thou shalt share with me.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Thank you Sir; Wou'd we had such a Windfall every day: But come, Sir, you must make haste, this is the Critical Minute; if you miss it, you lose Biancha.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Thy Counsel's good, away; I'll buy a Ring, and Pay the Priest with some of Woodall's Money, Ha, ha, hah.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Margaret, Geraldo and Sawny.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Walk your Horses down the Hill before, we shall reach London time enough, 'tis a fair Night; How bright and goodly the Moon shines.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: The Moon! the Sun, 'tis not the Moon-light now.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I say 'tis the Moon that Shines so Bright.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I say 'tis the Sun that shines so Bright.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Now by my Mothers Son, and that's my Self, it shall be the Moon-light, or what I please, before you set Sight of your Father's House; Sirrah, go fetch the Horses back; Evermore Crost, and Crost, and nothing but Crost?

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Say, as he sayes, or we shall never go.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Forward, I Pray Sir, since we are come so far; And be it Sun or Moon, or what you please; Nay, if you call it a Rush-Candle, henceforth it shall be so for me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I say 'tis the Moon.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed, but I say nay, Sir, Out, out, a Lies.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I know 'tis the Moon.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay then you Lie, 'tis the Blessed Sun.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why Heaven be Blest for it, 'tis even what you have a mind to; Pray let us forward.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Petruchio, go thy wayes, the Field is Won.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well, forward, forward; Now the Bowl runs with a Right Byas, but soft, here's Company.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Boy, Bid the Coachman drive gently down the Hill; I wonder I meet nor overtake no Passengers to day; stay, I think here be some.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I will have one bout more with thee Peg; Good-morrow Gentle Lady; Which way Travel you? Come hither Peg; Didst thou ever behold so Exquisite a Beauty as this Fair Virgin beares about. Go to her Peg, and Salute her.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Are you Mad, tis an Old Man.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Beat back agen then, still Cross? Will you do it?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Why i'th' Deel's Name, What mean ye? it's nea bonny Lass Sir; S'breed, it's an aw faw Thefe.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: He'll make this Old Man Mad.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You Budding Virgin, so fair, so sweet, so fresh, which way Travel you? How happy shou'd we be in the Enjoyment of so fair a Fellow Traveller.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: The Dee'l has built a Bird's Nest in your Head; Gud ye'r as mad as he; and he as Mad as gin he were the Son of a March Hare, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Why what do ye mean Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why now now Peg, I hope thou art not Mad: A Virgin Quotha! 'tis an Old Wrinckled Wither'd Man.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Reverend Sir, Pardon my mistaking eyes, that have been so dazled with the Moon (Sun I mean.) I cou'd not distinguish you; I now perceive you are a Grave Old Man, pray excuse me.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Indeed you are a Merry Lady; your encounter has amaz'd me. But I like such Chearful Company; I am for London to see a Son of mine, that went lately from me thither.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: We shall be glad of your Company; you must pardon my Wifes Errour, she has not slept well to Night; and I cou'd not perswade her, but she wou'd come out Fasting, which makes her Fancy a little extravagant.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: The Dee'l O' my Saul but you are a false Trundle Taile Tike, the Dee'l a bit hee'd lat her eat these three days Sir.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Curse upon your Excuse, and the Cause of it; I cou'd have eaten my Shooe-Soules, if I might have had 'em Fry'd.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Your Name I beseech you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Lio.
sp.p: I am Call'd, Sir Lyonell Winlove in the Country.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Father to young Mr. Winlove?

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: The same Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Then I am happy indeed to have met you; I can tell you some News, perhaps may not be Unwelcome to you. Your Son is in a fair probability of Calling me Brother within these Two dayes.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: How so, I pray Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why he's upon Marrying my Wifes Sister, my Lord Beaufoyes youngest Daughter. A brave Match, I can assure you, and a Sweet Bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud she's tea gued for any man but Saundy; Gud Gin poor Saundy had her in Scotland, Wun's I'de sea Swing her about.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: You Amaze me! Is this true? or have you a mind, like a pleasant Traveller, to break a Jest on the Company you overtake?

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Upon my Word, Sir, 'tis very true; 'twas so design'd; but I don't think he'll Marry her, he's Forsworn if he do.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: You make me Wonder more and more.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Mind him not, he's a Party Concern'd, 'tis true.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p:
Pray Gentlemen let's make haste, I must look after this Business, it soundes strangely, he wou'd not do't without my Consent; he's my
only Son, my Heir, the Prop of my Family, I must be careful.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I see you are Jealous Sir; but you need not; he cannot have a better Match.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: I doubt it not, if all be fair; I should be glad of my Lord Beaufoyes Allyance, he was my School-fellow; but Time, I doubt, has worn out our Old Acquaintance; Gentlemen, I must hasten to prevent the worst.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: What mean ye Sir? Yea will nea bawk the Bonna Lad, and tak fro his mattle Sir.

sp.speaker: Gera.
sp.p: Well, Petruchio, thou hast put me in a Heat, have at my Widdow now.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: How good you are my Faire one: Iamy, Ar't sure the Priest is ready for us?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir; Pray make hast, some Devil or other may come else and Cross it. Don't stay Thrumming of Caps; Here, Body o' me away, here's VVoodall, shift for your selves, all will be spoyl'd else.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Be sure you seize on her, and Clap her into a Chair, and one stop her mouth; fear not, I'll save you harmless.

sp.speaker: 1st. Fellow.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: What a Devil makes this Rogue Poaching here?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Tum, te Dum, te Dum; Sing Old Coale of London.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Now Iamy, What Walk you here for.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Why to look about me; Te Dum, te Dum, &c,

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: They say your Master is to be Marry'd to Madam Biancha to day.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Why then we'll be merry at Night; Te Dum, te Dum, &c.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: The Rogue won't be gone; What, Hast no Business? Thou look'st as if thou hadst not Drank to day, there's something for thee, go get thy Mornings Draught.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: I thank your Worship: Will you take part of a Pot of Ale and a Toast.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.l: No Sirrah, I Drank Coffee this morning.
So, he's gone; I wonder Mounsieur appears not with Biancha.

div.stage: Enter Petruchio, Margaret, Sir Lyonell, Geraldo, and Sauny, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Ha, Who comes there?

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: Now you are there Ill take my Leave; Your Servant.

sp.speaker: Petr.
sp.p: Sir Lyonell, you are Wellcome to Town; There's your Sons Lodgings; my Father Lives on the other side; thither we must, and therefore here I take my Leave.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: Pray stay a little, may be he's not within; if so, I'll wait upon you to the Lord Beaufoy.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: O' my Saul, nea can cou'd have Beg'd (Knocks.) Dunner better then this awd Theife has done.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: They are all busy within Sir, you must Knock Louder if you mean to be heard.

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: Who is that Knocks, as if he wou'd Beat down the Gate.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Is Mr. Winlove within?

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: He is within, but not to be spoken with.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: What if a Man bring him a Hundred Pounds or Two, to make Merry withall.

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: Keep your Hundred Pounds for your self, he shall need none as long as I Live.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, I told you, Sir, Your Son was well Belov'd in London. D'ye hear Sir, leaving your Frivelous Circumstances, pray tell him, His Father's just now come out of the Countrey to see him, and is here at the Door to speak with him.

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: That is a Lye Sir; his Father came to Town yesterday, and is now here Looking out at Window.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyo.
sp.p: The Devil he is; Are you his Father?

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: I Sir; so his Mother says, if I may believe her.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Can they Hang him for having twa Fathers Sir? Gud and 'twas sea, poor Sawndy wou'd be Hang'd sure enough.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why, Hast thou Two Fathers?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud have I, and Twa, and Twa to that Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why how now Gentlemen, this is flat Knavery, to take another Man's Name upon you.

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: Lay hands upon this Villain, I believe he means to Cheat some body here, under my Counter-Name,

sp.speaker: Iam.
Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Come hither Crack Hemp.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: You may save me that Labour, and come to me, if you have any thing to say to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Gome hither you Rogue, What have you forgot me?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Forgot you Sir? I cou'd not forget you; for I never saw you in all my Life before.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: You notorious Villain, Didst thou never see thy Master's Father, Sir Lyonell Winlove?

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: What my Worshipfull Old Master? Yes marry Sir: See where his Worship Looks out of the Window.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Does he so Sir? I'll make you find him below stayres.

sp.speaker: Iam.
sp.p: Help, help, here's a Mad-man will Murder me.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Dea Caw your sel Iamy? And wull ye be Beten by an aw faw Theefe? An yea Caw your sel Iamy cance meare, l'se bang ye tea Clootes, breed a Gud will I Sir.

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: Help Son, help Brother Beaufoy, Iamy will be kill'd.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Prethee Peg stand by to see this Controversy.

div.stage: Enter Snatchpenny with Servants, Beaufoy and Tranio.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: 'Sheart 'tis Sir Lyonell; but we must bear it a little time: Sir, What are you that offer to Beat my Servant?

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: What am I, Sir; Nay, What are you, Sir? O Heaven what do I see! O fine Villains, I'me undone, while I play the Good Husband at home in the Countrey, my Son, and my Servants spend my Estate Lavishly at London.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Your Son sal allow you Siller to keep an Awd Wutch to rub your Shins; And what to anger wou'd ye ha meer Sir.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: How now, What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is the Man Frantick?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Sir, You seem a sober Antient Gentleman by your Habit; but your Words shew you a Madman: Why Sir, What Concerns it you what Rich Cloaths I wear? I thank my good Father, I am able to maintain it.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Thy Father! O Villain! he's a Hemp-dresser in Partha.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Mara the Deel stuff his Wem fow a Hemp, and his Dam Spin it out at his Arse.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You mistake, you mistake; VVhat d'ye think his Name is?

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: His Name; as if I knew not his Name; I have Bred him up e're since he was Three Years old, and his Name is Tranio.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: Away, away, mad Ass, his Name is Winlove; my only Son, and Heir to all my Estate in the Vale of Evesham.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Heavens! he has murther'd his Master; lay hold on him, I charge you in the King's Name, O my Son, tell me thou Villain, Where is my Son VVinlove?

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Run for an Officer to carry this mad Knave to the Jayle; Lay hold on him I charge ye, and see him forth-coming.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Awa, awa with the Hampdresser Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Carry me to the Jayle ye Villaines!

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Hold Gentlemen; Your Blessing Father.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Son Petruchio VVellcome. You have it, and you Peg, how d'ye? Know ye any thing of this matter?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: My Lord, take heed what you do; so much I know, I dare Swear this is Sir Lyonell VVinlove, and that a Counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: VVuns, I think sea tea, gud an ye please I'se take the Covenant on't.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: So durst I Swear too almost.

sp.speaker: Snat.
sp.p: Swear if thou durst.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Sir I dare not Swear Point Blank.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: You had best Swear, I am not VVinlove neither.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Yes, I know you to be Mr. VVinlove.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Away with the Doater'd, to the Jayle with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Are you all setled to do mischief to me? VVhy my Lord Beausoy methinks you might know me.

sp.speaker: Tran.
sp.p: Away with him to my Lodgings for the present, 'till we can get a Constable to charge him upon, we shall have a hubbub in the Streets, drag him I say.

sp.speaker: Sir. Lyon.
sp.p: Rogues, Villains, Murderers! I shall have Justice.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: These are strange Passages, I know not what to think, of 'em; but I am glad Biancha came not when they were here, sure my Mounsier will not fail me.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Now my Biancha I am truly Happy, our Loves shall like the Spring be ever growing.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: But how shall we Escape my Fathers Anger.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Fear not, I'll warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O here's Biancha, how now Mounsier brave, What fancy's this?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: O Mounsieur te Vous la Menes, How d'ye do good Mr. Woodall, how d'ye like my new Bride?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: How, how, how, Sir, your Bride? Seize on her quickly.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Hands off, she's my Wife, touch her who dares; Will you have your Teeth pickt? What d'ye think of giving 20 Peeces to teach your Mistriss French.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: O Rogue, I'll have thee hang'd.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Or 40 Peeces to buy a Pair of Gloves, to let you Steal Madam Biancha: this Ring was bought with some of it, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Down with him, down with him, a damn'd Rascal.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: I, do, Which of you has a mind to breath a Vein?

sp.speaker: 2 Fell.
sp.p: Nay if she be his Wife we dare not touch her.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: I'll fetch some body that shall, O Devil.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Ay do, I am your poor Mounsieur, ha, ha, ha; Fear not Biancha, he'll fetch 'em all I know, I warrant thee we shall appease thy Father Easily.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Trust me Sir, I fear the Storm.

div.stage: Enter Beaufoy, Tranio, Petruchio, Margaret, Sauny, Snatchpenny, Jamy, Sir Lyonell, Woodall, and Attendants.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: That Rogue, that Damn'd Counterfit Frenchman has stolne your Daughter and Marryed her, here they are.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Bless me, What do I see yonder my Father, in earnest? Dear Sir your Blessing, and your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: My Dear Son, Art thou alive? then take it.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: I must beg your Pardon too Sir.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: And I most Honoured Father.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why what's the Matter? What hast thou done? VVoodall tells me thou hast Married the Frenchman.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Me she has Married, but no Frenchman. The right VVinlove, Son to the right VVinlove is her Husband, and your Son in-Law.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed Sir, ye act twa parts, ye were but a Hamp-dresser in the last Act, Sir.

sp.speaker: Snatch.
sp.p: 'Tis time for us to be going, I feel one Ear going off already.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You amaze me▪ Are not you the Frenchman, Mr. VVoodall prefer'd to teach my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: No my Lord, he put on that Disguise to Court me, he is the true VVinlove.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Marry is he my Son, Sir.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Those were but 〈◊〉 of my making.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Here's Patching with a Mistriss, I'm sure I am Gull'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: But d'ye hear Sir? Have you Married my Daughter without my Consent.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Come my Lord, now you must know me; I will beg both their Pardons, and Secure her a Jointure worthy her Birth and Fortune.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: You are a Father now Indeed.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir Lyonell excuse my rashness I accept your noble Proffer, you are forgiven.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed Sir, we sal nere go to Dunner Sir, the Deel forgat and forgive you aw, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: But where is that Rogue that would have sent me to Jayle? I'll slit his Nose for him.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: I must beg his Pardon, for he did all for my Sake.

sp.speaker: Sir Lyon.
sp.p: Well Sir, for your Sake I Pardon him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen all to my house, we shall there end all our Doubts, and drownd our fears.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: Sir, I shall expect my Money back again, 'tis enough to loose my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: No Faith 'tis in better hands already, you'll but fool it away, you'll be hireing Frenchmen agen.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Well mock on, I'll in and eat out part of it.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Husband will you not go with my Father?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: First kiss me Peg, and I will.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: What in the midle of the Street.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What art thou Asham'd of me?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Not so Sir, but asham'd to kiss so openly.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why then let's home again, Sauny lead the way.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud the Deel a bit will Saundy Budge before Dunner, Sir.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Nay I will give thee a kiss, nay pray now stay.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: So is not this well? come my sweet Peg.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Sister I hope we shall be friends now.

sp.speaker: Ma • g.
sp.p: I was never Foes with you.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: Come fairest, all the Storms are overblown; Love hath both Wit and Fortune of her own.

div.head: ACT V.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: BUt is't Possible Sister, he shu'd have us'd you thus?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Had I serv'd him as bad as Eve did Adam, he coud not have us'd me worse; but I am resolv'd now I'm got home again I'll be reveng'd, I'll muster up the Spight of all the Curs'd Women since Noahs Flood to do him Mischeif, and add new Vigour to my Tongue; I have not par'd my Nails this fortnight, they are long enough to do him some Execution, that's my Comfort.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Bless me Sister, how you talk.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Thou art a Fool Biancha, come Learn of me; thou art Married to a Man too, thou dost not know but thou mayst need my Councel, and make good use on't; Thy Husband bares thee fair yet, but take heed of going home with him, for when once he has thee within his verge, 'tis odds he'll have his freaks too; there's no trusting these Men: Thy temper is soft and easy, thou must Learn to break him, or he'll break thy Heart.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: I must Confess I shou'd be Loath to be so us'd, but sure Mr. VVinlove is of a better Disposition.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Trust him and hang him, they'r all alike; Come thou shalt be my Schollar, learn to Frown, and cry out for unkindness, but brave Anger, thou hast a Tongue, make use on't; Scould, Fight, Scratch, Bite, any thing, still take Exceptions at all he does, if there be Cause or not, if there be reason for't he'll Laugh at thee. I'll make Petruchio glad to wipe my Shoes, or walk my Horse, ere I have done with him.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Peace Sister, our Husbands are both here.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Thou Child I am glad on't, I'll speak louder,

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well Brother VVinlove now we are truly happy, never were Men so blest with two such Wives.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: I am glad to hear you say so Sir, my own I'm sure Im blest in.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Yours, why Biancha's a Lyon, and Margaret a meer Lamb to her: I tell thee Winlove, there's no Man living tho I say't, (but 'tis no matter since she does not hear me) that has a Wife so gentle, and so active and affable, poor thing I durst be sworn she wou'd walk barefoot a hundred Miles to do me good.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No but she wou'd not, nor one Mile neither.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Now have at your Luggs, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: O Peg, art thou there? How dost thou do my Dear?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You may go look, What's that to you?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Stand o' yer guard Sir, Gud Saundy will put on his head Peice.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I am glad to hear thee say thou'rt well introth.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Never the better for you, which you shall sind.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay I know thou lov'st me, Prithee take up my Glove Peg.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I take up your Glove; Marry come up, command your Servants, look you there it lyes.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I am glad to see thee merry, poor wanton Rogue.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, you think you are in the Country but you are mistaken, the case is alter'd, I am at home now, and my own disposer; Go swagger at your greazy Lubber there, your Patient Wife will make you no more Sport, she has a Father will allow her Meat and Lodging, and another gaits Chamber-Maid then a Highlander.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud an ye were a top of Grantham Steple that aw the Toon may hear what a Scanden Queen ye are, out, out.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Why what's the matter Peg? I never saw thee in so jolly a Humour, sure thou hast been Drinking.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud has she, haud ye tang, ye faw dranken Swine, out, out, out, was ye tak a Drink and nere tak Saundy to yee, out, out, out.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: 'Tis like I have, I am the sitter to talk to you, for no sober Woman is a Companion for you.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Troth thou sayst right, we are excellently Matcht.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Well mark the end on't, Petruchio prithee come hither, I have something to say to you.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: De ye nea budge a foot Sir, Deel a my saul bo she'll Scratch your eyn out.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Well, your Pleasure Madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: First thou art a Pittiful fellow, a thing beneath me, which I scorn and Laugh at, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: She holds her own yet I see.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I know not what to call thee, thou art no Man, thou coudst not have a Woman to thy Mother, thou paltry, Scurvy, ill condition'd fellow, dost thou not tremble to think how thou hast us'd me; What are you silent Sir? Biancha see, Looks he not like a Disbanded Officer, with that hanging dog look there? I must eat nothing because your Cook has Roasted the Mutton dry, as you us'd to have it 〈…〉 your Worship was a Batchellor, I must not go to Bed neither, because 〈…〉 are Damp.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Mark you Peg; What a strange Woman are you to Discourse openly the Fault of your Servants in your own Family.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, this wont serve your turn; your Old Stock of Impudence won't carry you off so: I'll speak your Fame, and tell what a fine Gentleman you are▪ how Valliantly you, and halfe a Douzen of your Men, got the better of a Single Woman, and made her lose her Supper,

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud she Lyes Sir; I wou'd a gin her an awd Boot tul • a made Tripes on, and it wod a hin bra Meat with Mustard, and she wou'd nea have it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: My Faults? No, good Squire of the Country, you thought to have Tam'd me, I warrant, in good time; why you see I am even with you; Your Quiet Patient Wife, that will go no more in the Country with you, but will stay in Town, to Laugh at your Wi • e Worship, and wish you more Wit.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I shou'd Laugh at that; why we are just now a going▪ Sauny go get the Horses ready quickly.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud will I Sir; I'se Saddle a Highland-Wutch to Carry your Bride; Gud she'll mount your Arse for you Madam.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Sirrah, touch a Horse, and I'll Curry your Coxcomb for you: No Sir, I won't say, Pray let me not go; but boldly, I won't go; you force me if you can or dare: You see I am not Tongue-ty'd, as silent as you thought you made me.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Prithee Peg, Peace a little, I know thou canst Speak, leave now, or thoul't have nothing to say to morrow.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yes, I'll say this over again, and something more if I can think on't, to a poor despised man of Clouts: Sister, how he smoakes now he's off his own Dunghill.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Prithee Peg leave making a Noise; I'faith thou'lt make my Head ach.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Noise? Why this is Silence to what I intend; I'll talk Louder than this, every Night in my Sleep.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: The Dee'l shall be your Bed fellow for Sawndy then.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I will learn to Rail at thee in all Languages; Thunder shall be soft-musick to my Tongue.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: The Dee'l a bit Scot's ye gat to brangle in, marry the Dee'l gi ye a Clap wi a French Thunder-bolt.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Very pretty; Prithee go on.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I'll have a Collection of all the Ill Names that ever was Invented, and call you over by 'em twice a-day.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: And have the Catalogue publish'd for the Education of young Scolds: Proceed Peg.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I'll have you Chain'd to a Stake at Billingsgate, and Baited by the fish-wives, while I stand to Hiss 'em on.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; Witty Peg, forward.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: You shan't dare to Blow your Nose, but when I bid you; you shall know me to be the Master.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Wuns gat her to the Stool of Repantance, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, I believe, thou wilt go in Breeches shortly; On, on; What have you no more on't? Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: D'ye Laugh and be Hang'd? I'll spoil your Sport.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Nay, Peg, Hands off; I thought you wou'd not have Disgrac'd your Good Parts, to come to Blows so soon; Prithee Chide on, thou can'st not believe what Delight I take to hear thee; It does become thee so well: What Pumpt dry already? Prithee talk more and longer, and faster, and sharper, this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I'll see you in the Indies before I'll do any thing to please you; D'ye like it?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Extreamly! On Peg, you'll cooll too fast.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Why then Mark me, if it were to save thee from Drowning, or Breaking thy Neck, I won't speak one word more to thee these Two Months.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Ah Gud an ye do nea Ly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
Nay, Good Peg, be not so hard-harted. What Melancholly all
• 'th' sudden? Come, get up, we'll send for the Fidlers, and have a Dance; Tho'lt break thy Elbow with Leaning on that hard Table: Sawny, go get your Mistriss a Cushion; Alas! I doubt she's not well; Look to her Sister.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Are you not well, Sister? What ail you? Pray speak Sister: Indeed, Brother, you have so Vext her, she'll be Sick.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Alas, alas! I know what's the matter with her, she has the Tooth-Ach. See how she holds her Cheek; the Wind has gotten into her Teeth, by keeping her Mouth open this Cold Weather.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Indeed it may be so Brother, she uses to be troubled with that Pain sometimes.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Without all Question; Poor Peg, I pitty thee; Which Tooth is it? Wilt thou have it Drawn, Peg? The Tooth-Ach makes Fooles of all the Physitians; there is no Cure, but Drawing: What say'st thou? Wilt thou have it pull'd out? Well, thou shalt. Sauny, Run, Sirrah, hard by, you know where my Barber Lives that Drew me a Tooth last Week, fetch him quickly; What d'ye stand staring at? Run and fetch him immediately, or I'll cut your Legs off.

sp.speaker: Saun
sp.p: Gud I'se fetch can to pull her head off an ye wull.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: This will make her find her Tongue agen, or else for certain she has lost it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Her Tongue, Brother? Alas! You see her Face is so Swell'd, she cannot speak.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: You Jest Brother; her Face is not swell'd. Pray let me see, Sister, I can't perceive it.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Not Swell'd? Why you are blind then; Prithee let her alone, you trouble her.

div.p: Here, Honest Barber, have you brought your Instruments?

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.p: Yes Sir; VVhat must I do?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You must Draw that Gentlewoman a Tooth there; Prithee do it neatly, and as gently as thou can'st; And, de hear me, take care you don't tear her Gums.

sp.speaker: Barber.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Hear ye Sir, Cou'd not ye Mistake? and pull her Tang out instead of her Teeth.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: I'll be gone, I can't endure to see her put to so much Pain.

sp.speaker: Barb.
sp.l: Pray, Madam, open your Mouth, that I may see which Tooth it is.
VVhy Sir, Did you send for me to Abuse me.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud be nea Angry, Ye ha ne aw yer Pay yet Sir. Cud ye not Mistake, and Draw her Tang in stead of her Teeth Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: No, no: But it seems now she wo' not have it Drawn: Go, there's something for your Paines however.

sp.speaker: Sau.
sp.p: Ye sid ha taken my Counsel Sir.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: This will not do, Sir. You cannot raise the Spirit you have laid, with all your Arts.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
I'll try; Have at her once more. VVinlove, you must assist me; I'll make her Stir, if I can't make her Speak. Look, look! alas! How Pale she is! She's gone o'th' sudden; Body O' me, she's stiff too; undone, undone, What an unfortunate Man am I? she's gone! she's gone! never had man so great a Loss as I; O Winlove, pity me, my poor Peg is Dead, dear Winlove call in my Father and the Company that they may share in this sad Spectacle, and help my Sorrows with their joyning Griefs.
Exit. Winlove. Speak, or by this hand I'll bury thee alive; Sauny thou feest in how sad a condition thy poor Master is in▪ thy good Mistriss is Dead, hast to the next Church and get the Bier and the Bearers hither, I'll have her buried out of hand; Run Sauny.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: An you'll mack her Dead, we'll bury her deep enough, we'll put her doon intill a Scotch Coalepit, and she shall rise at the Deel's arse o' Peake.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I will see that last Pious act Perform'd, and then betake my self to a willing Exile; my own Country's Hell, now my dear Peg has left it. Not yet, upon my Life I think thou hast a mind to be buried quick; I hope thou hast.

div.stage: Enter Winlove, Beaufoy, Sir Lyonell, Woodall, Biancha, Tranio, Jamy, &c.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Bless me Son Petruchio, Is my dear Daughter Dead?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Alas, alas, 'tis but too true, wou'd I had ta'ne her roome.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Why methinks she looks brisk, fresh and lively.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: So much Beauty as she had must needs leave some wanding remains to hover still about her face.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What could her Disease be?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Indeed I grieve to tell it, but truth must out, she Dyed for spight, she was strangely Infected.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Fye Sister, for shame speak, Will you let him abuse you thus?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Gentlemen you are my loving Friends and knew the Virtues of my matchless Wife, I hope you will accompany her Body to its long home.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We'll all wait on you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Thou wilt break her heart indeed.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I warrant you Sir, 'tis tougher then so.

div.stage: Enter Sauny and Bearers with a Beir.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: I bring you here vera gued Men, an she be nea Dead Sir, for a Croon more they'll bury her quick.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: O honest friends, you'r Wellcome, you must take up that Corps, how! hard-hearted, Why de ye not weep? the loss of so much Beauty and goodness, take her up, and lay her upon the Beir.

sp.speaker: 1 Bear.
sp.p: Why what d'ye mean Sir? She is not Dead.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Rogues, tell me such a Lye to my face? Take her up or I'll swinge ye.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Tak her up, tak her up, we'll mak her Dead Billy, ye'st a twa Croo • mear, tak her up Man.

sp.speaker: 1 Bear.
sp.p: Dead or alive all's one to us, let us but have our fees.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p:
There, nay she is stiff, however on with her, Will you not speak yet? So here take these Strings and bind her on the Beir, she had an active stirring body when she Liv'd, she may chance fall off the Hearse now she's Dead: So, now take her up and away, come Gentlemen you'll follow, I mean to carry her through the Strand as far as St. Iame's, People shall see what respect I bore her—She shall have so much Ceremony to attend her now she's Dead. There my Coach shall meet her and carry her into the Country, I'll have her laid in the Vault belonging to my Family, she shall have a Monument; some of you inquire me out a good Poet to write her Epitaph suitable to her Birth, Quallity and Conditions, Pitty the
remembrance of so many Virtues shou'd be lost; March on, I wou'd say more, but grief Checks my Tongue.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Father, Sister, Husband, Are you all Mad? Will you expose me to open shame? Rogues set me down you had best.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A Miracle! a Miracle! she Lives! Heaven make me thankful for't, set her down, Liv'st thou my Poor Peg?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Yes that I do, and will to be your Tormentor.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Out, out, gea her nea Credit, gud she's as Dead as mine Grannam, tak her, away with her, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Bless me my hopes are all vanisht agen, 'tis a Demon speaks within her Body; Take her up again, we'll bury 'em together.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Hold, hold, my dear Petruchio, you have overcome me, and I beg your Pardon, henceforth I will not dare to think a thought shall Cross your Pleasure, set me at Liberty, and on my knees I'll make my Recantation.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Victoria, victoria, the field is won.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Art thou in earnest Peg? May I believe thee?

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: You ken very well she was awway's a lying Quean when she was Living, and wull ye believe her now she's Dead?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: By all that's good not truth it self truer.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Then thus I free thee, and make thee Mistriss both of my self and all I have.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: S'breed bo ye`l nea gi Saundy tull her Sir?

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Take heed of giving away your Power, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I'll venture it, nor do I fear I shall repent my bargain.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I'm sure I will not give you Cause, y've taught me now what 'tis to be a Wife, and I'll still shew my self your humble Handmaid.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: My best Peg, we will change kindness and be each others Servant; Gentlemen why do you not Rejoyce with me?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I am so full of joy I cannot Speak, may you be happy, this is your Wedding day.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Shall Saundy get her a Bride-Cake, and Brake o'r her Head Sir? and wee's gatt us a good Wadding Dunner.

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: Save ye all Gentlemen; Have ye any Room for more Guess? I am come to make up the Chorus.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: My Noble Friend, VVellcome; VVhere have you been so long?

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: I have been about a little trivial Business; I am just now come from a VVedding.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: What VVedding I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: Troth e'en my own; I have ventur'd upon't at last: Madam, I hope you'l pardon me.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: Yes Sir; and so will this Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Are not you a Gentleman-Hampdresser?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: 'Tis e'en so, this proves to be VVinlove in earnest.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Good Gentlemen undo this Riddle; I'm all in the Dark.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: You shall know anon, in the mean time Believe it Gentlemen. VVe want another VVoman, or we might have a Dance.

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: My VViddow is within, she'll supply you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Good Peg go and wait on her, and you Biancha too.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I tell thee Geraldo, never had Man so Obedient and Loving a VVife as I have now, I defy the VVorld to equal her.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Nay, Brother, you must except her Sister.

sp.speaker: Geral.
sp.p: You must except mine too, or I shall have a hard Bargain of it; my VViddow is all Obedience.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I'll tell you what I'll do with you, I'll hold you Ten Pieces to be spent in a Collation on them, That mine has more Obedience than both them; to try which, each send for his VVife, and if mine come not first I'll lose my Bett.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Gud yeel lose your Siller sure enough Sir.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: A Match.

sp.speaker: VVood.
sp.p: I'll be your halves Geraldo, and yours Mr. VVinlove too.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Iamy, Go tell your Mistress, I desire her to come hither to me presently.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: A Piece more she does not come.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You'll lose Son, you'l lose; I know she`ll come.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I know she won`t; I find by Instinct I shall VVin my VVager.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Sir, she says she's busie, and she can`t leave Mr. Geraldo's Lady.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Look ye there now, come your Money.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: Prithee go again and tell my Wife I must needs speak with her immediately.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I shall win yours too as sure as in my Pocket.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: I warrant you no such matter, What will you give to be off your Bett?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: I won't take forty Shillings.

sp.speaker: Jam.
sp.p: Sir, she says you have no Business with her, if you have you may come to her.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Come produce, I knew 'twould be so; Sauny go and tell Peg from me, I command her to come to me instantly.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: I'se gar her gea wuth me Sir, or I'se put my Durke to the hilt in her Weam.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Yet you wont win, I'll hang for't if she'll come.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Yes but she will, as sure as you gave forty peices to Court Biancha, I'll venture them to twenty more upon't with you.

sp.speaker: Wood.
sp.p: Nay I have lost enough already.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Look ye here Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: O my Saul, she's can a daft gued Lass, she's at your Beck, steake her and kiss her Man.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I come to receive your Commands, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: All I have to say to thee Peg, is to bid thee demand ten pound of these two Gentlemen, thou hast Won it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: I, Sir, for what?

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Only for being so good natur'd to come when I send for you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: It was my duty Sir.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Come pay, pay, give it her, I'll not bate ye two pence.

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: There's mine.

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: And mine Sister, much good may it do ye.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: VVell Peg I'll find thee one Thousand Pound the more for this.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Bo what wull ye gi Saundy that halpt to mak her gued and tame? VVuns she was as VVild as a Galloway Coalt.

sp.speaker: VVin.
sp.p: Look here they come at last.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: VVhat did you send for me for?

sp.speaker: Win.
sp.p: VVhy to win me five Pound if you had been as obedient as you should a been.

sp.speaker: Bian.
sp.p: You have not known me long enough to venture so much upon my Duty, I have been my Sisters Schollar a little.

sp.speaker: Saun.
sp.p: Bo put her to Saundy to teach, Gud I'se mak her sea gentle ye may streake her and handle her all o're Sir,

sp.speaker: Ger.
sp.p: You might have got me five Pound if you had done as you should do.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: VVere it to do again you should be sure to loose.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.p: Fy Ladys, for shame, How dare you infringe that Duty which you justly owe your Husbands, they are our Lords and we must pay 'em Service.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: VVell said Peg, you must be their Tutor, come Son if youll have a Dance dispatch it quickly, the Musick's ready, and the Meat will be spoil'd.

sp.speaker: Pet.
sp.p: Come then, play, play.
sp.l: Now let us in, and Eate, the VVork is done,
VVhich neither Time nor Age can wear from Memory;
I've Tam'd the Shrew, but will not be asham'd,
If next you see the very Tamer Tam'd.
